WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. John Irwin Jamason.
Address Byemoor, Alberta.
Birthplace Manchester, England. Age 73 years old.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? June 1895.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Near Lacomb, Alberta.
Where had you been living before that? In England and United States.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Four and callers and visitors.
How far was it to your nearest store? Eight miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Rarely in winter and monthly in summer.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, tea, sugar, salt, in the late nineties. Dried apples and prunes, rice, small quantity of spice for flavoring, little sage for dressing, toilet soap and laundry soap at first, cod oil, salt, pepper, vinegar, oatmeal, beef pearl barley, flour, shorts and bran, rolled oats and pearl barley.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
Ogilvie Strong Bakers—3rd grade also Ogilvie's Glenora 2nd grade and then Hungarian and Royal Household—1st grade.

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 pounds later in larger quantities of 500 lbs.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
Best $2.25. 2nd grade was $1.75 and 3rd—$1.25 per 100 lbs.

How much did you use graham flour? Very little. We mixed shorts with flour.

Whole wheat flour? For porridge only.

Was flour milled locally? No. How far away? Brandon, Manitoba.
What year? 1895.

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
About 35 cents.

What other grain products did you use? Later we used some corn meal and pearl barley.

Cornmeal? Yes years after. Whole wheat? Yes. Farina? Yes years after.

Other? Rolled oats.
June 15, 1951

WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FAMILIES BUY?

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatoon Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name Mrs. John Irwin Jameson
Age 73 years old
Address 2300 4th Avenue, Edmonton
Birthplace Manchester, England

INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

1. That year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1896
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Near Lacombe, Alberta.
   Where had you been living before that? In England and United States.
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Four and callers.
   How far was it to your nearest store? Eight miles.
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Rarely in winter.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Bread flour, sugar, rice, salt, in the littlest quantities. Dried beans, dried peas, dried rice, small quantity of spices for flavoring, coffee, tea, sugar, flour, cleaning, toilet soap and laundry soap at first, coal oil, salt, pepper, vinegar, butter, beef, pearl barley.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
   Ogilvie's Strong Flour, Ogilvie's 3rd grade flour, Ogilvie's Household Grade.

In what quantities did you buy 100 pounds, 100 pounds, or 500 lbs.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
   Best $2.25, 2nd grade $1.75 and 3rd $1.25 per 100 lbs.

How much did you use graham flour? Very little. We mixed whole wheat flour per porridge only.

Was flour milled locally? No. How far away? Brandon, Manitoba.

What year? 1895.

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   About 35 cents.

What other grain products did you use? Later we used some cornmeal and pearl barley.

Cornmeal? Yes years after. Whole wheat? Yes. Pearl? Yes.

Other? Rolled oats.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.

How did you grind it? We did not have a small mill even an old-fashioned coffee mill some of the neighbors used. We used ours for grinding the barley for coffee.

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 4 pounds at a time except for fruit.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? There was not any. 6 cents a pound.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Lyle's golden syrup.

What size tin of syrup did you usually buy? 2 pounds.

At what price? I do not remember. Perhaps 20 cents.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From one cow.

Butter? Made it. Eggs? Kept a few hens.

What was the price of butter? 8 cents a pound. Of eggs? 10 cents a dozen or less.

Did you pack eggs for winter? No, how? Later I packed them in coarse salt sometimes in vats. A neighbor packed hers in wood ashes.

Did you make butter? Yes. Cheese. No. Only sour milk cheese.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Mostly rabbits, prairie chickens, partridges, and in the winter deer meat and some beef and pork.

How did you get fresh meat? By shooting it in season early years and later by killing our own cattle and pigs.

How often did you get fresh meat? Beef very rarely. Pork often.

How did you preserve meat? By dry curing it with salt, sugar, saltpeter, and also by pickling in brine.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No and never at Lacombe.

If so what year was it organized? Not until the late 1920's and on from there.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Rabbits, ducks, geese, prairie chickens, partridges and deer.

For how long? In the early years of the nineties and up to now.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Fish was usually caught in the early winter and kept frozen. If caught later it was salted.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh and cured.

Kinds? Mullet, Jack fish, pickerel and goldeyes.
Did you grind your own wheat for flour? No.

How did you grind it? We did not have a mill so we used a hand mill.

Was the coffee mill used for coffee? Yes.

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 4 pounds at a time except for fruit.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? There was no any. 6 cents a pound.

What brand or golden syrup did you usually buy? 2 pounds.

What size tin of syrup did you usually buy? 2 pounds.

At what price? I do not remember. Perhaps 20 cents.

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

butterfly made it.

What was the price of butter? 8 cents a pound.

Did you keep eggs for winter? No.

Did you keep a few hens.

Did you peel eggs for winter? No.

Did you keep chickens for eggs?

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese?

Did you make cheese? No.

Only sour milk cheese.

MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Mostly rabbits!

Prairie chickens, partridges, and in the winter deer meat.

How did you get fresh meat? By shooting it in season early years and later by killing our own cattle and pigs.

How often did you get fresh meat? Bear very rarely. Pork often.

How did you preserve meat? By dry curing it with salt, sugar, pepper, and also by pickling in brine.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No end never at Leamore.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Rabbits, ducks, geese, prairie chickens, partridges and deer.

For how long? In the early years of the nineteen twenties and up to now.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Fish was usually caught in the early winter and kept frozen. If caught later it was salted.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh and cured.

Kinds? Mullet, Jack fish, pickerel and goldeyes.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Ram Lak and Ridgways black tea.

At what price? 45 cents a pound.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) None in early years.

Price? ..... What other beverages were used? Tea made from wild mint and coffee made from roasted barley also milk.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 25 cents a bushel. Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes. If not, where from? Grown in Alberta.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1895.

Potatoes? Yes. Cabbages? No luck. Carrots? Yes. Onions? Yes.

Turnips? Yes. Beets? Yes. Also lettuce, radishes and peas.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? .5 pounds.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Both ways. Also by the pound.

What weight? 20 pounds. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? By the box or pound.

What was the price of prunes? About 10 cents by the pound.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)? Mostly dried apples at Christmas time. We could get a few pounds of raisins and currants and a small quantity of candied orange and lemon peel for baking.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

peas? Yes. corn? No. beans? No. Saskatoons? yes.

Other foods? Gooseberries, strawberries, rhubarb, currants, raspberries and cranberries (wild fruit).

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1896.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1915.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning and making preserves and jellies. Yes.

To what extent? Bought cases of fruit of all kinds and baskets of grapes.

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes for many years from vinegar Mother brought from Ireland by a neighbour in 1895 also from dried apples and sugar by an American Settler in 1896.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Dried Yeast Cakes.

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes. Salt rising. No. Sour dough sometimes.

Did you buy baking powder? Yes. Baking soda? Yes.

Cream of tartar? Yes. Did you make your own baking powder? At first I made it of Cream of Tartar and one teaspoonful of Bicarbonate of Soda mixed well together. We also used sour milk or buttermilk and soda for making pancakes, bannocks, scones and biscuits. I also made Bachelor biscuits out of flour, salt, little soda and water. Spoon biscuits were very good.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood. Some coal in 1901.

Where did you get your fuel? The wood grew on our farm and the coal came from the Red Deer River 35 miles away.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Gasoline and coal oil stoves. Coal oil stoves were not much used in the prairies until about 1910. Gasoline stoves were used much later, perhaps twenty years. We have propane gas stoves, lights radiants, furnaces and refrigerators since 1928 or 1949. Many farmers have had electricity in their homes since 1928. The plants are mostly Delco engines.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Open fireplaces were used in 1892 and earlier. 1889.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)
No., I always used a wood stove until 1901. Then coal and wood.

By whom was your first cook stove made? McClary's, London, Ont.

What year was it purchased? September, 1893. Price? $20.00.

What types of utensils did you use? (iron, copper, tin, homemade)
Iron and tin saucepans, iron cooking kettles, copper tea kettle and also an iron one, tin pie plates and basins.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)
Enamel basins, earthenware bowls and pudding dishes, covered small crocks and jars.

When did you first see enamel ware? ...........................................

Aluminum? ........................................................................................

We used mostly tin and iron cooking utensils in 1892 and until 1910 on the prairie. Crocks were used to put milk in to "set" and also for pudding dishes etc. Crocks were used for stews made in the oven. They had a crock cover. These were used by the settlers from 1889 to about 1910. Crock jars were also used for packing down butter for winter use, and cooked meat in the summer. Latter were filled in with melted fat. It kept well when stored in cold, dark cellars and took the place of fresh meat. This report covers a space of fifty years.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible). Mostly paper was used to wrap parcels of food. Much stronger paper than is used today. Tea was always in a tin caddy, except the green tea, called uncolored Japan, which was in stiff paper or thin cardboard packages. Jam was in small wooden pails and imported jam in large tins. Flour, cereals, salt, sugar, all in 100 pounds were in strong cotton and burlap bags and barrels held larger quantities.

Tea was always in a tin can, except the green tea called uncolored Japan, which was in small wooden pails and imported jam in large tins. Flour was in stiff paper or thin cardboard boxes. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State approximately the month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast (continued next page)
17. (Continued)

Breakfast

Oatmeal or wheats porridge up to 1903.
Cracked wheat was also much used but took a long time to cook.
Warmed over potatoes, bacon and eggs.
Buttered toast, jam or marmalade. Tea for beverage.

Dinner

Roast meat, stewed meat, or fried meat, sometimes fish.
Potatoes, vegetables with gravy.
A milk pudding, bread, no butter. Water for beverage.

Supper

Cold meat or eggs or perhaps fish.
Warmed up potatoes.
Fruit, if possible, or scones, jam, or cake. Black tea for beverage.

This was our menu all the year round with more cold meats in the summer and hotter dishes in the winter varied with pork and beans, head cheese, scrambled eggs and salads.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? ....... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Our first Christmas as a family was in 1895. There was my father aged 42 years. My brother aged 21 years. Myself aged 17 years. My sister aged 14 years. We had two guests. An elderly gentleman aged 50 years and a younger one aged 22 years. Our dinner was roast beef, potatoes, carrots and turnips boiled and mashed together, gravy, Christmas pudding and white sauce with apples, nuts and homemade candy and a little Port wine. I was the housekeeper and cooked the dinner myself.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No we were never in that condition but a good many of our neighbors were as we afterwards found out. One family in 1895 existed that winter on rabbits, turnips, potatoes, black bread made from 4X flour (that the Indians used), coffee made from roasted barley. They had no milk, butter, sugar or fruit of any kind. Some fish had been caught early in December and some of the neighbors gave them beef fat to fry them in. Of course everyone had salt. One family, I heard of fat to the south of us, lived on rabbits and turnips for weeks having neither potatoes or bread and barley coffee which was a favorite drink with all of us. The new settlers suffered great hardships in the early days and would have starved but for the results. In 1896 all the gardens were frozen. We had no vegetables of any kind. Grain was only fit for cattle feed and poor at that. The winter of 1896-1897 rabbits had a disease and were unfit for food. There was great hardship as well among the Indians on the reservation north of Lacombe.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

One great difference was the lack of fresh citrus fruits. Corn, cucumbers, and tomatoes could not be grown in ordinary gardens about 1910 on account of the June frosts. Then, in the early days we could not buy glass sealers to preserve our fruit, meat, vegetables and pickles. A few had brought Mason jars from the United States in the "nineties" but these were inadequate as no fresh rubber rings could be purchased. We preserved our fruit as our grandmother did and put the vegetables in the cellar.

This was our menu all the year round with more cold meats in
summer and hotter dishes in the winter varied with pork
sausages, head cheese, scrambled eggs and salads.

18. What year did you have your first Christmas dinner in
our new home?...1925

Our first Christmas dinner was eaten by my parents and two
sisters. My father was 47 years old, my mother 36 years old,
and I was 17 years old. We had roast beef, potatoes, carrots and
cabbage, and a little Port wine. I was the housekeeper and cooked
the dinner myself.

19. Were you ever dependent upon your parents for food?

In the early days we had no vegetables of any kind. Some fish had been
caught and some of the neighbors had been able to trade for
vegetables. In 1966 all the gardens were frozen. We had no fresh
vegetables or any kind. Some fish had been caught and some
of the neighbors had been able to trade for vegetables.

The winter of 1966-1967 rabbits had a disease and were unfit
for food. There was great hardship as well among the Indians
on the reservation north of Lacome.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals
in the earliest days as compared with today.

One great difference was the lack of fresh citrus fruits.
Corn, cucumbers and tomatoes could not be grown in ordinary
gardens about 1910 on account of the June frost. Then, in the
early days we could not buy glass sealers to preserve our fruit,
meat, vegetables and pickles. A few had brought season jars
from the United States. In the "nineties" but these were
inadequate as no fresh rubber rings could be purchased. We
preserved our fruits as our grandmother did and put the vegetables
in the cellar.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

As we were not fond of canned foods except salmon, corn, tomatoes and applesauce we did not buy any others. I always canned at least a hundred quarts of fruit, vegetables, meat, chicken, etc. Made lots of jars of various kinds of pickles.

A farmer's wife was a very busy person in the old days. Money was too scarce to spend on food in cans that we could and did cure and preserve ourselves.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if extra space is needed).

When I left the settlements around Lacombe in 1903 we went seventy miles south and east and built up a ranch. A fairly large log house, lots of other buildings and corrals. We had to take enough provisions to last for six months so bought everything in bulk. Of course our first year was the hardest for we could not tell exactly how much we needed. However, we started with 1,000 pounds of flour, 2-30 pound sacks of Rolled Oats, 10 pounds black tea, 5 pounds coffee, 10 pounds cocoa, 25 pounds rice, 25 pounds beans, cases of dried apples, peaches, apricots, pears and prunes, cases of canned corn, tomatoes and salmon, 2 barrels salt and 20 gallons of coal oil, 8 cans of lye for soap making, 20 bars of soap (laundry), 20 cases of toilet soap, 5 pounds currants, 10 pounds raisins, 3 pounds candied peel, 5 pounds cocoanut and other small items. Winter clothing, towels, etc. In February we ran short of coal oil, cattle salt and sugar (we had taken 200 pounds) and had to make a trip out to the nearest trading post 25 miles away. A bad blizzard came on. There were no trails in those days as the country was settled until two years later. It was travelling as the crow flies and hard on for anyone who was caught in a blizzard. A good many people owed their lives to the sagacity of their horses on trips like that one. My husband's favorite mare brought him safely home. How she picked out the way he never knew.

In the early years of the "nineties" there were very few cattle among the early settlers and very few pigs and chickens. Eggs were scarce and considered a luxury so was beef and pork products. The American settlers came in covered wagons and perhaps had a cow and a calf and sometimes a sow. The horses were not acclimatized and many of them died the first winter. The sufferings of some of the settlers was intense owing to the lack of proper food and severe cold. Wood was plentiful and so were the rabbits which were a Godsend to many. It was late in the fall when the settlers finished the long trek from Iowa, Kansas and Nebraska to Alberta and winter was upon them. Some went back to the United States to work there a while and came back. The settlers who came later on from the United States came by train shipping horses, cattle, pigs, chickens and machinery in box cars. They also brought money with them and bought up the homesteads from the earlier settlers. They and their descendants are some of our best citizens today. There are still some of the real old timers from the United States here and their families. Great praise is due to the women of the early pioneer days for the privations they suffered, the hardships they endured and the fine families they raised.

The way we canned fruit in 1896 (if we had plenty of jars) was to put hay in the bottom of a wash boiler we had. On this we put our jars filled with fruit, sugar and water. We used Mason jars and old rubbers and metal caps. We filled up the boiler with water to the caps and then boiled them for two hours.
Let cool and stored in cellar. We canned wild gooseberries, saskatoons, raspberries, made preserves of strawberries, currants, and blueberries. Jelly and jam of cranberries. Preserved rhubarb out of our own garden. All the fruit we canned and otherwise preserved was wild fruit we picked around and in the vicinity of our home.

I am sorry I can not remember the exact prices. Ten or fifteen years ago I could have filled it out better.

Mrs. John Jamerson.

It is to the amazing courage and endurance of the early United States settlers that Alberta owes so much. They were wonderful pioneers taking their experiences as a matter of course without complaining, as so many of the later settlers did, who came came ten to fifteen years later. This small tribute I pay to them. Many of the children and grandchildren of the early United States pioneers are some of our most prosperous and enterprising farmers of today.

We also burned grease lights made of any kind of grease but mostly beef tallow. This we melted and put in a saucer with a piece of cotton an inch wide. We lit the cotton which hung over the side and the grease would burn for hours. One of our neighbors from Ontario had a mould and could make a proper wick. Sometimes the roads were very heavily drifted and our coal oil done so we kept a few wax candles and burned grease lights.

The men, when out of tobacco, smoked kinniknack leaves dried, also the inner bark of the Red Willow dried. An old Indian told my father about this.

Mrs. John Irwin Jamerson

Box 67, Repemoon, Alta.
